ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned basic skills in reading, writing, and listening to German.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The homework in this class sometimes felt unorganized and beyond what was covered in class. The listening assignments always felt far above the level of the class.
This course was great in class. However, I feel that the at-home assignments very quickly became overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I probably would not recommend this class to another student. It was a lot of work for little pay off and the organization was not helpful to me.

Yes, but only if the syllabus is changed. This is not the fault of the instructor but rather the Goethe Institute, which designed the syllabus. By the end of the semester, I was still unable to form written sentences in German. This was remedied by a few hours of YouTube videos in which I learned the interactions between articles and the three gendersalong with plural and singularin the nominative, accusative, dative, and genitive cases. Without this knowledge it is simply not possible to learn to read and write. I know the course wants to take things slow and drill the basics, but these are the basics. I found the hand-holding excessive and actually counterproductive to learning: if the textbook holds our hands and gives us pre-set multiple choice responses which are already conjugated and declined, instead of making us spontaneously decide whether to say, e.g, "zu" vs "nach" or "ins" vs "im," we are just not going to learn.
Yes this course is an amazing introductory language course!
